We can first solve for the depreciation by dividing the cost given by the number of years.

$$\begin{aligned}
D&=\dfrac{\$786,000}{8}\\
&=\$98,250
\end{aligned}$$

Substitute the known values to the formula for accounting break-even point.

$$\begin{aligned}
Q&=\dfrac{\$725,000+\$98,250}{\$48-\$25}\\
&=\dfrac{\$823,250}{\$23}\\
&=35793.48\\
&\approx 35793
\end{aligned}$$

This means that the accounting break-even point is at $35,793$ units.

To solve for the operating cash flow, we can use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
OCF&=(P-v)\times Q-FC
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the known values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
OCF&=(\$48-\$25) \times 35793-\$725,000\\
&=\$23 \times 35793-\$725,000\\
&=\$823,239-\$725,000\\
&=\$98,239
\end{aligned}$$

Since we already know the operating cash flow, we can substitute the value to the formula for DOL:

$$\begin{aligned}
DOL&=1+\dfrac{\$725,000}{\$98,239}\\
&=1+7.38\\
&=8.38
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values to the formula, we can get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Base-case cashflow}&=\$98,239\times(1-0.22)\\
&+(0.22 \times \$98,250)\\
&=\$76,626.42+\$21,615.00\\
&=\$98,241.42
\end{aligned}$$

The base-case cashflow is $\$98,241.42$

The **net present value (NPV)** is essentially the difference between the cash inflow and the cash outflow multiplied to the annuity rate in a given time. In this case, since the time period is 8 years and the rate is $10\%$. Using an annuity table we can see that tha rate is To do this, we can use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
NPV_{base}&=-\text{Initial cost}+\text{Present cash flow}\\
&=-\$786,000+\$98,241.42 \times 4.4873\\
&=-\$440,838.72
\end{aligned}$$

With the given base NPV value, we can see that the present cash flow is not enough to offset the initial cost for the project. This means that the sensitivity of the NPV to the quantity sold can only be noticed if the change in quantity is increased significantly. 

Therefore, a 500-unit decrease will keep the base NPV negative which means that the present cashflow is still not enough to offset the expenses.

**c.** For this, we need to solve for the new OCF by subtracting $\$1$ from the variable cost. 

Using the same formula in **Step 5**, we will get:
$$\begin{aligned}
OCF&=(\$48-\$24) \times 35793-\$725,000\\
&=\$23 \times 35793-\$725,000\\
&=\$859,032-\$725,000\\
&=\$134,032
\end{aligned}$$

We can then solve for the sensitivity by taking the difference between the old and new operating cashflows and divide them by the change in variable cost.

$$\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{\Delta OCF}{\Delta v}&=\dfrac{\$134,032-\$98,239}{\$24-\$25}\\
&=-\$35,793
\end{aligned}$$

This means that if the variable cost is reduced by $\$1$, then the operating cashflow will also decrease by $\$35,793$. This shows that the operating cashflow and the variable cost are directly proportional since a decrease in one will result in a decrease on the other.
